message.content: Caveat: The messages below were generated by the user while running local commands. DO NOT respond to these messages or otherwise consider them in your response unless the user explicitly asks you to.

<local-command-stdout>Version 0.2.21:
• Fuzzy matching for /commands

Version 0.2.26:
• New /approved-tools command for managing tool permissions
• Word-level diff display for improved code readability
• Fuzzy matching for slash commands

Version 0.2.30:
• Added ANSI color theme for better terminal compatibility
• Fixed issue where slash command arguments weren't being sent properly
• (Mac-only) API keys are now stored in macOS Keychain

Version 0.2.31:
• Custom slash commands: Markdown files in .claude/commands/ directories now appear as custom slash commands to insert prompts into your conversation
• MCP debug mode: Run with --mcp-debug flag to get more information about MCP server errors

Version 0.2.32:
• Interactive MCP setup wizard: Run "claude mcp add" to add MCP servers with a step-by-step interface
• Fix for some PersistentShell issues

Version 0.2.34:
• Vim bindings for text input - enable with /vim or /config

Version 0.2.36:
• Import MCP servers from Claude Desktop with `claude mcp add-from-claude-desktop`
• Add MCP servers as JSON strings with `claude mcp add-json <n> <json>`

Version 0.2.37:
• New /release-notes command lets you view release notes at any time
• `claude config add/remove` commands now accept multiple values separated by commas or spaces

Version 0.2.41:
• MCP server startup timeout can now be configured via MCP_TIMEOUT environment variable
• MCP server startup no longer blocks the app from starting up

Version 0.2.44:
• Ask Claude to make a plan with thinking mode: just say 'think' or 'think harder' or even 'ultrathink'

Version 0.2.47:
• Press Tab to auto-complete file and folder names
• Press Shift + Tab to toggle auto-accept for file edits
• Automatic conversation compaction for infinite conversation length (toggle with /config)

Version 0.2.49:
• Previous MCP server scopes have been renamed: previous "project" scope is now "local" and "global" scope is now "user"

Version 0.2.50:
• New MCP "project" scope now allows you to add MCP servers to .mcp.json files and commit them to your repository

Version 0.2.53:
• New web fetch tool lets Claude view URLs that you paste in
• Fixed a bug with JPEG detection

Version 0.2.54:
• Quickly add to Memory by starting your message with '#'
• Press ctrl+r to see full output for long tool results
• Added support for MCP SSE transport

Version 0.2.59:
• Copy+paste images directly into your prompt
• Improved progress indicators for bash and fetch tools
• Bugfixes for non-interactive mode (-p)

Version 0.2.61:
• Navigate menus with vim-style keys (j/k) or bash/emacs shortcuts (Ctrl+n/p) for faster interaction
• Enhanced image detection for more reliable clipboard paste functionality
• Fixed an issue where ESC key could crash the conversation history selector

Version 0.2.63:
• Fixed an issue where MCP tools were loaded twice, which caused tool call errors

Version 0.2.66:
• Print mode (-p) now supports streaming output via --output-format=stream-json
• Fixed issue where pasting could trigger memory or bash mode unexpectedly

Version 0.2.67:
• Shared project permission rules can be saved in .claude/settings.json

Version 0.2.69:
• Fixed UI glitches with improved Select component behavior
• Enhanced terminal output display with better text truncation logic

Version 0.2.70:
• Network commands like curl are now available for Claude to use
• Claude can now run multiple web queries in parallel
• Pressing ESC once immediately interrupts Claude in Auto-accept mode

Version 0.2.72:
• Updated spinner to indicate tokens loaded and tool usage

Version 0.2.74:
• Added support for refreshing dynamically generated API keys (via apiKeyHelper), with a 5 minute TTL
• Task tool can now perform writes and run bash commands

Version 0.2.75:
• Hit Enter to queue up additional messages while Claude is working
• Drag in or copy/paste image files directly into the prompt
• @-mention files to directly add them to context
• Run one-off MCP servers with `claude --mcp-config <path-to-file>`
• Improved performance for filename auto-complete

Version 0.2.82:
• Added support for --disallowedTools
• Renamed tools for consistency: LSTool -> LS, View -> Read, etc.

Version 0.2.93:
• Resume conversations from where you left off from with "claude --continue" and "claude --resume"
• Claude now has access to a Todo list that helps it stay on track and be more organized

Version 0.2.96:
• Claude Code can now also be used with a Claude Max subscription (https://claude.ai/upgrade)

Version 0.2.98:
• Fixed an issue where auto-compact was running twice

Version 0.2.100:
• Fixed a crash caused by a stack overflow error
• Made db storage optional; missing db support disables --continue and --resume

Version 0.2.102:
• Improved thinking triggering reliability
• Improved @mention reliability for images and folders
• You can now paste multiple large chunks into one prompt

Version 0.2.105:
• Claude can now search the web
• Moved system & account status to /status
• Added word movement keybindings for Vim
• Improved latency for startup, todo tool, and file edits

Version 0.2.106:
• MCP SSE server configs can now specify custom headers
• Fixed a bug where MCP permission prompt didn't always show correctly

Version 0.2.107:
• CLAUDE.md files can now import other files. Add @path/to/file.md to ./CLAUDE.md to load additional files on launch

Version 0.2.108:
• You can now send messages to Claude while it works to steer Claude in real-time
• Introduced BASH_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT_MS and BASH_MAX_TIMEOUT_MS env vars
• Fixed a bug where thinking was not working in -p mode
• Fixed a regression in /cost reporting
• Deprecated MCP wizard interface in favor of other MCP commands
• Lots of other bugfixes and improvements

Version 0.2.117:
• Breaking change: --print JSON output now returns nested message objects, for forwards-compatibility as we introduce new metadata fields
• Introduced settings.cleanupPeriodDays
• Introduced CLAUDE_CODE_API_KEY_HELPER_TTL_MS env var
• Introduced --debug mode

Version 0.2.125:
• Breaking change: Bedrock ARN passed to `ANTHROPIC_MODEL` or `ANTHROPIC_SMALL_FAST_MODEL` should no longer contain an escaped slash (specify `/` instead of `%2F`)
• Removed `DEBUG=true` in favor of `ANTHROPIC_LOG=debug`, to log all requests

Version 1.0.0:
• Claude Code is now generally available
• Introducing Sonnet 4 and Opus 4 models

Version 1.0.1:
• Added `DISABLE_INTERLEAVED_THINKING` to give users the option to opt out of interleaved thinking.
• Improved model references to show provider-specific names (Sonnet 3.7 for Bedrock, Sonnet 4 for Console)
• Updated documentation links and OAuth process descriptions

Version 1.0.4:
• Fixed a bug where MCP tool errors weren't being parsed correctly

Version 1.0.6:
• Improved edit reliability for tab-indented files
• Respect CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR everywhere
• Reduced unnecessary tool permission prompts
• Added support for symlinks in @file typeahead
• Bugfixes, UI polish, and tool reliability improvements

Version 1.0.7:
• Renamed /allowed-tools -> /permissions
• Migrated allowedTools and ignorePatterns from .claude.json -> settings.json
• Deprecated claude config commands in favor of editing settings.json
• Fixed a bug where --dangerously-skip-permissions sometimes didn't work in --print mode
• Improved error handling for /install-github-app
• Bugfixes, UI polish, and tool reliability improvements

Version 1.0.8:
• Fixed Vertex AI region fallback when using CLOUD_ML_REGION
• Increased default otel interval from 1s -> 5s
• Fixed edge cases where MCP_TIMEOUT and MCP_TOOL_TIMEOUT weren't being respected
• Fixed a regression where search tools unnecessarily asked for permissions
• Added support for triggering thinking non-English languages
• Improved compacting UI

Version 1.0.10:
• Added markdown table support
• Improved streaming performance

Version 1.0.11:
• Claude Code can now also be used with a Claude Pro subscription
• Added /upgrade for smoother switching to Claude Max plans
• Improved UI for authentication from API keys and Bedrock/Vertex/external auth tokens
• Improved shell configuration error handling
• Improved todo list handling during compaction

Version 1.0.17:
• We now emit messages from sub-tasks in -p mode (look for the parent_tool_use_id property)
• Fixed crashes when the VS Code diff tool is invoked multiple times quickly
• MCP server list UI improvements
• Update Claude Code process title to display "claude" instead of "node"

Version 1.0.18:
• Added --add-dir CLI argument for specifying additional working directories
• Added streaming input support without require -p flag
• Improved startup performance and session storage performance
• Added CLAUDE_BASH_MAINTAIN_PROJECT_WORKING_DIR environment variable to freeze working directory for bash commands
• Added detailed MCP server tools display (/mcp)
• MCP authentication and permission improvements
• Added auto-reconnection for MCP SSE connections on disconnect
• Fixed issue where pasted content was lost when dialogs appeared

Version 1.0.21:
• Improved editing of files with tab-based indentation
• Fix for tool_use without matching tool_result errors
• Fixed a bug where stdio MCP server processes would linger after quitting Claude Code

Version 1.0.22:
• SDK: Renamed `total_cost` to `total_cost_usd`

Version 1.0.23:
• Released TypeScript SDK: import @anthropic-ai/claude-code to get started
• Released Python SDK: pip install claude-code-sdk to get started

Version 1.0.24:
• Improved /mcp output
• Fixed a bug where settings arrays got overwritten instead of merged

Version 1.0.25:
• Slash commands: moved "project" and "user" prefixes to descriptions
• Slash commands: improved reliability for command discovery
• Improved support for Ghostty
• Improved web search reliability

Version 1.0.27:
• Streamable HTTP MCP servers are now supported
• Remote MCP servers (SSE and HTTP) now support OAuth
• MCP resources can now be @-mentioned
• /resume slash command to switch conversations within Claude Code

Version 1.0.28:
• Slash commands: Fix selector display during history navigation
• Resizes images before upload to prevent API size limit errors
• Added XDG_CONFIG_HOME support to configuration directory
• Performance optimizations for memory usage
• New attributes (terminal.type, language) in OpenTelemetry logging

Version 1.0.29:
• Improved CJK character support in cursor navigation and rendering

Version 1.0.30:
• Custom slash commands: Run bash output, @-mention files, enable thinking with thinking keywords
• Improved file path autocomplete with filename matching
• Added timestamps in Ctrl-r mode and fixed Ctrl-c handling
• Enhanced jq regex support for complex filters with pipes and select

Version 1.0.31:
• Fixed a bug where ~/.claude.json would get reset when file contained invalid JSON

Version 1.0.32:
• Updated loopback config for litellm
• Added forceLoginMethod setting to bypass login selection screen

Version 1.0.33:
• Improved logging functionality with session ID support
• Added prompt input undo functionality (Ctrl+Z and vim 'u' command)
• Improvements to plan mode

Version 1.0.34:
• Fixed a memory leak causing a MaxListenersExceededWarning message to appear

Version 1.0.35:
• Added support for MCP OAuth Authorization Server discovery

Version 1.0.36:
• Web search now takes today's date into context
• Fixed a bug where stdio MCP servers were not terminating properly on exit

Version 1.0.37:
• Remove ability to set `Proxy-Authorization` header via ANTHROPIC_AUTH_TOKEN or apiKeyHelper

Version 1.0.38:
• Released hooks. Special thanks to community input in https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/712. Docs: https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks

Version 1.0.39:
• New Active Time metric in OpenTelemetry logging

Version 1.0.40:
• Fixed a bug causing API connection errors with UNABLE_TO_GET_ISSUER_CERT_LOCALLY if `NODE_EXTRA_CA_CERTS` was set

Version 1.0.41:
• Hooks: Split Stop hook triggering into Stop and SubagentStop
• Hooks: Enabled optional timeout configuration for each command
• Hooks: Added "hook_event_name" to hook input
• Fixed a bug where MCP tools would display twice in tool list
• New tool parameters JSON for Bash tool in `tool_decision` event

Version 1.0.42:
• Added tilde (`~`) expansion support to `/add-dir` command

Version 1.0.43:
• Fixed a bug where the theme selector was saving excessively
• Hooks: Added EPIPE system error handling

Version 1.0.44:
• New /export command lets you quickly export a conversation for sharing
• MCP: resource_link tool results are now supported
• MCP: tool annotations and tool titles now display in /mcp view
• Changed Ctrl+Z to suspend Claude Code. Resume by running `fg`. Prompt input undo is now Ctrl+U.

Version 1.0.45:
• Redesigned Search (Grep) tool with new tool input parameters and features
• Disabled IDE diffs for notebook files, fixing "Timeout waiting after 1000ms" error
• Fixed config file corruption issue by enforcing atomic writes
• Updated prompt input undo to Ctrl+\_ to avoid breaking existing Ctrl+U behavior, matching zsh's undo shortcut
• Stop Hooks: Fixed transcript path after /clear and fixed triggering when loop ends with tool call
• Custom slash commands: Restored namespacing in command names based on subdirectories. For example, .claude/commands/frontend/component.md is now /frontend:component, not /component.

Version 1.0.48:
• Fixed a bug in v1.0.45 where the app would sometimes freeze on launch
• Added progress messages to Bash tool based on the last 5 lines of command output
• Added expanding variables support for MCP server configuration
• Moved shell snapshots from /tmp to ~/.claude for more reliable Bash tool calls
• Improved IDE extension path handling when Claude Code runs in WSL
• Hooks: Added a PreCompact hook
• Vim mode: Added c, f/F, t/T

Version 1.0.51:
• Added support for native Windows (requires Git for Windows)
• Added support for Bedrock API keys through environment variable AWS_BEARER_TOKEN_BEDROCK
• Settings: /doctor can now help you identify and fix invalid setting files
• `--append-system-prompt` can now be used in interactive mode, not just --print/-p.
• Increased auto-compact warning threshold from 60% to 80%
• Fixed an issue with handling user directories with spaces for shell snapshots
• OTEL resource now includes os.type, os.version, host.arch, and wsl.version (if running on Windows Subsystem for Linux)
• Custom slash commands: Fixed user-level commands in subdirectories
• Plan mode: Fixed issue where rejected plan from sub-task would get discarded

Version 1.0.52:
• Added support for MCP server instructions

Version 1.0.53:
• Updated @-mention file truncation from 100 lines to 2000 lines
• Add helper script settings for AWS token refresh: awsAuthRefresh (for foreground operations like aws sso login) and awsCredentialExport (for background operation with STS-like response).

Version 1.0.54:
• Hooks: Added UserPromptSubmit hook and the current working directory to hook inputs
• Custom slash commands: Added argument-hint to frontmatter
• Windows: OAuth uses port 45454 and properly constructs browser URL
• Windows: mode switching now uses alt + m, and plan mode renders properly
• Shell: Switch to in-memory shell snapshot to fix file-related errors

Version 1.0.55:
• Clarified knowledge cutoff for Opus 4 and Sonnet 4 models
• Windows: fixed Ctrl+Z crash
• SDK: Added ability to capture error logging
• Add --system-prompt-file option to override system prompt in print mode

Version 1.0.56:
• Windows: Enabled shift+tab for mode switching on versions of Node.js that support terminal VT mode
• Fixes for WSL IDE detection
• Fix an issue causing awsRefreshHelper changes to .aws directory not to be picked up

Version 1.0.57:
• Added support for specifying a model in slash commands
• Improved permission messages to help Claude understand allowed tools
• Fix: Remove trailing newlines from bash output in terminal wrapping

Version 1.0.58:
• Added support for reading PDFs
• MCP: Improved server health status display in 'claude mcp list'
• Hooks: Added CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR env var for hook commands

Version 1.0.59:
• SDK: Added tool confirmation support with canUseTool callback
• SDK: Allow specifying env for spawned process
• Hooks: Exposed PermissionDecision to hooks (including "ask")
• Hooks: UserPromptSubmit now supports additionalContext in advanced JSON output
• Fixed issue where some Max users that specified Opus would still see fallback to Sonnet

Version 1.0.60:
• You can now create custom subagents for specialized tasks! Run /agents to get started

Version 1.0.61:
• Transcript mode (Ctrl+R): Changed Esc to exit transcript mode rather than interrupt
• Settings: Added `--settings` flag to load settings from a JSON file
• Settings: Fixed resolution of settings files paths that are symlinks
• OTEL: Fixed reporting of wrong organization after authentication changes
• Slash commands: Fixed permissions checking for allowed-tools with Bash
• IDE: Added support for pasting images in VSCode MacOS using ⌘+V
• IDE: Added `CLAUDE_CODE_AUTO_CONNECT_IDE=false` for disabling IDE auto-connection
• Added `CLAUDE_CODE_SHELL_PREFIX` for wrapping Claude and user-provided shell commands run by Claude Code

Version 1.0.62:
• Added @-mention support with typeahead for custom agents. @<your-custom-agent> to invoke it
• Hooks: Added SessionStart hook for new session initialization
• /add-dir command now supports typeahead for directory paths
• Improved network connectivity check reliability

Version 1.0.63:
• Windows: Fixed file search, @agent mentions, and custom slash commands functionality

Version 1.0.64:
• Agents: Added model customization support - you can now specify which model an agent should use
• Agents: Fixed unintended access to the recursive agent tool
• Hooks: Added systemMessage field to hook JSON output for displaying warnings and context
• SDK: Fixed user input tracking across multi-turn conversations
• Added hidden files to file search and @-mention suggestions

Version 1.0.65:
• IDE: Fixed connection stability issues and error handling for diagnostics
• Windows: Fixed shell environment setup for users without .bashrc files

Version 1.0.68:
• Fix incorrect model names being used for certain commands like `/pr-comments`
• Windows: improve permissions checks for allow / deny tools and project trust. This may create a new project entry in `.claude.json` - manually merge the history field if desired.
• Windows: improve sub-process spawning to eliminate "No such file or directory" when running commands like pnpm
• Enhanced /doctor command with CLAUDE.md and MCP tool context for self-serve debugging
• SDK: Added canUseTool callback support for tool confirmation
• Added `disableAllHooks` setting
• Improved file suggestions performance in large repos

Version 1.0.69:
• Upgraded Opus to version 4.1

Version 1.0.70:
• Performance: Optimized message rendering for better performance with large contexts
• Windows: Fixed native file search, ripgrep, and subagent functionality
• Added support for @-mentions in slash command arguments

Version 1.0.71:
• Background commands: (Ctrl-b) to run any Bash command in the background so Claude can keep working (great for dev servers, tailing logs, etc.)
• Customizable status line: add your terminal prompt to Claude Code with /statusline

Version 1.0.72:
• Ask permissions: have Claude Code always ask for confirmation to use specific tools with /permissions

Version 1.0.73:
• MCP: Support multiple config files with `--mcp-config file1.json file2.json`
• MCP: Press Esc to cancel OAuth authentication flows
• Bash: Improved command validation and reduced false security warnings
• UI: Enhanced spinner animations and status line visual hierarchy
• Linux: Added support for Alpine and musl-based distributions (requires separate ripgrep installation)

Version 1.0.77:
• Bash tool: Fix heredoc and multiline string escaping, improve stderr redirection handling
• SDK: Add session support and permission denial tracking
• Fix token limit errors in conversation summarization
• Opus Plan Mode: New setting in `/model` to run Opus only in plan mode, Sonnet otherwise

Version 1.0.80:
• UI improvements: Fix text contrast for custom subagent colors and spinner rendering issues

Version 1.0.81:
• Released output styles, including new built-in educational output styles "Explanatory" and "Learning". Docs: https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/output-styles
• Agents: Fix custom agent loading when agent files are unparsable

Version 1.0.82:
• SDK: Add request cancellation support
• SDK: New additionalDirectories option to search custom paths, improved slash command processing
• Settings: Validation prevents invalid fields in .claude/settings.json files
• MCP: Improve tool name consistency
• Bash: Fix crash when Claude tries to automatically read large files

Version 1.0.83:
• @-mention: Support files with spaces in path
• New shimmering spinner

Version 1.0.84:
• Fix tool_use/tool_result id mismatch error when network is unstable
• Fix Claude sometimes ignoring real-time steering when wrapping up a task
• @-mention: Add ~/.claude/\* files to suggestions for easier agent, output style, and slash command editing
• Use built-in ripgrep by default; to opt out of this behavior, set USE_BUILTIN_RIPGREP=0

Version 1.0.85:
• Status line input now includes session cost info
• Hooks: Introduced SessionEnd hook

Version 1.0.86:
• Added /context to help users self-serve debug context issues
• SDK: Added UUID support for all SDK messages
• SDK: Added `--replay-user-messages` to replay user messages back to stdout

Version 1.0.88:
• Fixed issue causing "OAuth authentication is currently not supported"
• Status line input now includes `exceeds_200k_tokens`
• Fixed incorrect usage tracking in /cost.
• Introduced `ANTHROPIC_DEFAULT_SONNET_MODEL` and `ANTHROPIC_DEFAULT_OPUS_MODEL` for controlling model aliases opusplan, opus, and sonnet.
• Bedrock: Updated default Sonnet model to Sonnet 4

Version 1.0.90:
• Settings file changes take effect immediately - no restart required

Version 1.0.93:
• Windows: Add alt + v shortcut for pasting images from clipboard
• Support NO_PROXY environment variable to bypass proxy for specified hostnames and IPs

Version 1.0.94:
• Vertex: add support for global endpoints for supported models
• /memory command now allows direct editing of all imported memory files
• SDK: Add custom tools as callbacks
• Added /todos command to list current todo items

Version 1.0.97:
• Settings: /doctor now validates permission rule syntax and suggests corrections

Version 1.0.106:
• Windows: Fixed path permission matching to consistently use POSIX format (e.g., `Read(//c/Users/...)`)

Version 1.0.109:
• SDK: Added partial message streaming support via `--include-partial-messages` CLI flag

Version 1.0.110:
• /terminal-setup command now supports WezTerm
• MCP: OAuth tokens now proactively refresh before expiration
• Fixed reliability issues with background Bash processes

Version 1.0.111:
• /model now validates provided model names
• Fixed Bash tool crashes caused by malformed shell syntax parsing

Version 1.0.112:
• Transcript mode (Ctrl+R): Added the model used to generate each assistant message
• Addressed issue where some Claude Max users were incorrectly recognized as Claude Pro users
• Hooks: Added systemMessage support for SessionEnd hooks
• Added `spinnerTipsEnabled` setting to disable spinner tips
• IDE: Various improvements and bug fixes

Version 1.0.113:
• Deprecated piped input in interactive mode
• Move Ctrl+R keybinding for toggling transcript to Ctrl+O

Version 1.0.115:
• Improve thinking mode display with enhanced visual effects
• Type /t to temporarily disable thinking mode in your prompt
• Improve path validation for glob and grep tools
• Show condensed output for post-tool hooks to reduce visual clutter
• Fix visual feedback when loading state completes
• Improve UI consistency for permission request dialogs

Version 1.0.117:
• Add Ctrl-R history search to recall previous commands like bash/zsh
• Fix input lag while typing, especially on Windows
• Add sed command to auto-allowed commands in acceptEdits mode
• Fix Windows PATH comparison to be case-insensitive for drive letters
• Add permissions management hint to /add-dir output

Version 1.0.119:
• Fix Windows issue where process visually freezes on entering interactive mode
• Support dynamic headers for MCP servers via headersHelper configuration
• Fix thinking mode not working in headless sessions
• Fix slash commands now properly update allowed tools instead of replacing them

Version 1.0.120:
• Fix input lag during typing, especially noticeable with large prompts
• Improved VSCode extension command registry and sessions dialog user experience
• Enhanced sessions dialog responsiveness and visual feedback
• Fixed IDE compatibility issue by removing worktree support check
• Fixed security vulnerability where Bash tool permission checks could be bypassed using prefix matching

Version 1.0.123:
• Bash permission rules now support output redirections when matching (e.g., `Bash(python:*)` matches `python script.py > output.txt`)
• Fixed thinking mode triggering on negation phrases like "don't think"
• Fixed rendering performance degradation during token streaming
• Added SlashCommand tool, which enables Claude to invoke your slash commands. https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands#SlashCommand-tool
• Enhanced BashTool environment snapshot logging
• Fixed a bug where resuming a conversation in headless mode would sometimes enable thinking unnecessarily
• Migrated --debug logging to a file, to enable easy tailing & filtering

Version 1.0.124:
• Set `CLAUDE_BASH_NO_LOGIN` environment variable to 1 or true to to skip login shell for BashTool
• Fix Bedrock and Vertex environment variables evaluating all strings as truthy
• No longer inform Claude of the list of allowed tools when permission is denied
• Fixed security vulnerability in Bash tool permission checks
• Improved VSCode extension performance for large files

Version 1.0.126:
• Enable /context command for Bedrock and Vertex
• Add mTLS support for HTTP-based OpenTelemetry exporters

Version 2.0.0:
• New native VS Code extension
• Fresh coat of paint throughout the whole app
• /rewind a conversation to undo code changes
• /usage command to see plan limits
• Tab to toggle thinking (sticky across sessions)
• Ctrl-R to search history
• Unshipped claude config command
• Hooks: Reduced PostToolUse 'tool_use' ids were found without 'tool_result' blocks errors
• SDK: The Claude Code SDK is now the Claude Agent SDK
• Add subagents dynamically with `--agents` flag

Version 2.0.1:
• Skip Sonnet 4.5 default model setting change for Bedrock and Vertex
• Various bug fixes and presentation improvements

Version 2.0.5:
• IDE: Fix IME unintended message submission with Enter and Tab
• IDE: Add "Open in Terminal" link in login screen
• Fix unhandled OAuth expiration 401 API errors
• SDK: Added SDKUserMessageReplay.isReplay to prevent duplicate messages

Version 2.0.8:
• Update Bedrock default Sonnet model to `global.anthropic.claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929-v1:0`
• IDE: Add drag-and-drop support for files and folders in chat
• /context: Fix counting for thinking blocks
• Improve message rendering for users with light themes on dark terminals
• Remove deprecated .claude.json allowedTools, ignorePatterns, env, and todoFeatureEnabled config options (instead, configure these in your settings.json)

Version 2.0.9:
• Fix regression where bash backgrounding stopped working

Version 2.0.10:
• Rewrote terminal renderer for buttery smooth UI
• Enable/disable MCP servers by @mentioning, or in /mcp
• Added tab completion for shell commands in bash mode
• PreToolUse hooks can now modify tool inputs
• Press Ctrl-G to edit your prompt in your system's configured text editor
• Fixes for bash permission checks with environment variables in the command

Version 2.0.11:
• Reduced system prompt size by 1.4k tokens
• IDE: Fixed keyboard shortcuts and focus issues for smoother interaction
• Fixed Opus fallback rate limit errors appearing incorrectly
• Fixed /add-dir command selecting wrong default tab</local-command-stdout>

1→//
     2→//  DesignSystem.swift
     3→//  Generated from CSS OKLCH tokens -> sRGB (Light/Dark)
     4→//  Font: San Francisco (system fonts)
     5→//
     6→//  Usage:
     7→//  let theme = DesignTheme.defaultLight
     8→//  Text("Hello").font(theme.font(.body)).foregroundStyle(theme.color(.foreground))
     9→//
    10→
    11→import SwiftUI
    12→
    13→public enum DSColorToken: String, CaseIterable {
    14→  case background
    15→  case foreground
    16→  case card
    17→  case cardforeground
    18→  case popover
    19→  case popoverforeground
    20→  case primary
    21→  case primaryforeground
    22→  case secondary
    23→  case secondaryforeground
    24→  case muted
    25→  case mutedforeground
    26→  case accent
    27→  case accentforeground
    28→  case destructive
    29→  case destructiveforeground
    30→  case success
    31→  case successforeground
    32→  case warning
    33→  case warningforeground
    34→  case info
    35→  case infoforeground
    36→  case border
    37→  case input
    38→  case ring
    39→  case chart1
    40→  case chart2
    41→  case chart3
    42→  case chart4
    43→  case chart5
    44→  case sidebar
    45→  case sidebarforeground
    46→  case sidebarprimary
    47→  case sidebarprimaryforeground
    48→  case sidebaraccent
    49→  case sidebaraccentforeground
    50→  case sidebarborder
    51→  case sidebarring}
    52→
    53→public enum DSTextStyle {
    54→  case largeTitle, title1, title2, title3, headline, subheadline, body, callout, footnote, caption1, caption2
    55→}
    56→
    57→public struct DesignTheme {
    58→  public let colors: [DSColorToken: Color]
    59→  public let colorScheme: ColorScheme
    60→  public init(colors: [DSColorToken: Color], colorScheme: ColorScheme) {
    61→    self.colors = colors
    62→    self.colorScheme = colorScheme
    63→  }
    64→  // Color accessor
    65→  public func color(_ token: DSColorToken) -> Color { colors[token] ?? .clear }
    66→  // Font accessor using SF system fonts (Dynamic Type)
    67→  public func font(_ style: DSTextStyle) -> Font {
    68→    switch style {
    69→    case .largeTitle: return .system(.largeTitle, design: .default)
    70→    case .title1:     return .system(.title, design: .default)
    71→    case .title2:     return .system(.title2, design: .default)
    72→    case .title3:     return .system(.title3, design: .default)
    73→    case .headline:   return .system(.headline, design: .default)
    74→    case .subheadline:return .system(.subheadline, design: .default)
    75→    case .body:       return .system(.body, design: .default)
    76→    case .callout:    return .system(.callout, design: .default)
    77→    case .footnote:   return .system(.footnote, design: .default)
    78→    case .caption1:   return .system(.caption, design: .default)
    79→    case .caption2:   return .system(size: 11, weight: .regular, design: .default)
    80→    }
    81→  }
    82→}
    83→
    84→extension Color {
    85→  init(hex: String, colorSpace: Color.RGBColorSpace = .sRGB) {
    86→    let hex = hex.trimmingCharacters(in: CharacterSet.alphanumerics.inverted)
    87→    var int: UInt64 = 0
    88→    Scanner(string: hex).scanHexInt64(&int)
    89→    let r = Double((int >> 16) & 0xFF) / 255.0
    90→    let g = Double((int >> 8) & 0xFF) / 255.0
    91→    let b = Double(int & 0xFF) / 255.0
    92→    self.init(colorSpace, red: r, green: g, blue: b)
    93→  }
    94→}
    95→
    96→// MARK: - Theme Configuration
    97→
    98→/// Global theme configuration for Display P3 gamut support
    99→public class ThemeConfig {
   100→  /// Use Display P3 color space for wider gamut on modern devices
   101→  /// Defaults to true for modern iOS devices (iPhone 7+, iPad Pro 9.7"+)
   102→  /// Most devices since 2016 support P3, so we default to true
   103→  public static var useP3: Bool = true
   104→
   105→  /// Helper to detect P3 support from a UITraitCollection
   106→  /// Usage: Call this from a view context to update useP3 dynamically
   107→  /// Example: ThemeConfig.updateGamutSupport(from: traitCollection)
   108→  public static func updateGamutSupport(from traitCollection: UITraitCollection) {
   109→    #if os(iOS)
   110→    useP3 = traitCollection.displayGamut == .P3
   111→    #endif
   112→  }
   113→}
   114→
   115→// MARK: - Theme Factories
   116→
   117→public extension DesignTheme {
   118→  static let defaultLight = DesignTheme(colors: Self.makeColors(light: true), colorScheme: .light)
   119→  static let defaultDark  = DesignTheme(colors: Self.makeColors(light: false), colorScheme: .dark)
   120→
   121→  private static func makeColors(light: Bool) -> [DSColorToken: Color] {
   122→    let map = light ? lightHex : darkHex
   123→    let colorSpace: Color.RGBColorSpace = ThemeConfig.useP3 ? .displayP3 : .sRGB
   124→    var out: [DSColorToken: Color] = [:]
   125→    for (k, v) in map {
   126→      // Convert hyphenated keys to camelCase to match enum cases
   127→      let tokenKey = k.replacingOccurrences(of: "-", with: "")
   128→      if let token = DSColorToken(rawValue: tokenKey) {
   129→        out[token] = Color(hex: v, colorSpace: colorSpace)
   130→      }
   131→    }
   132→    return out
   133→  }
   134→
   135→  // Raw hex dictionaries (generated)
   136→  private static let lightHex: [String:String] = [
   137→  "background": "#F8FAFC",
   138→  "foreground": "#0F172A",
   139→  "card": "#FFFFFF",
   140→  "card-foreground": "#1E293B",
   141→  "popover": "#FFFFFF",
   142→  "popover-foreground": "#1E293B",
   143→  "primary": "#3590F3",

   145→  "secondary": "#E5E7EB",

   164→  "chart-3": "#4338CA",
   165→  "chart-4": "#3730A3",

   167→  "sidebar": "#EEF2F6",

   170→  "sidebar-primary-foreground": "#FFFFFF",
   171→  "sidebar-accent": "#22D3A6",
   172→  "sidebar-accent-foreground": "#07362B",
   173→  "sidebar-border": "#D7DEE7",
   174→  "sidebar-ring": "#5AAAF6"
   175→]
   176→  private static let darkHex: [String:String]  = [
   177→  "background": "#0E1116",
   178→  "foreground": "#E6EAF0",
   179→  "card": "#151A21",
   180→  "card-foreground": "#E6EAF0",
   181→  "popover": "#151A21",
   182→  "popover-foreground": "#E6EAF0",
   183→  "primary": "#61AEF8",
   184→  "primary-foreground": "#0A0E14",
   185→  "secondary": "#2D3748",
   186→  "secondary-foreground": "#D1D5DB",
   187→  "muted": "#1F2730",

   189→  "accent": "#22D3A6",

   191→  "destructive": "#FF6B70",
   192→  "destructive-foreground": "#0A0E14",
   193→  "success": "#36D17D",
   194→  "success-foreground": "#0A0E14",
   195→  "warning": "#F6C35A",
   196→  "warning-foreground": "#0A0E14",
   197→  "info": "#3B82F6",
   198→  "info-foreground": "#FFFFFF",
   199→  "border": "#2A3440",
   200→  "input": "#1A2029",
   201→  "ring": "#5AAAF6",
   202→  "chart-1": "#61AEF8",

   204→  "chart-3": "#4F46E5",
   205→  "chart-4": "#4338CA",
   206→  "chart-5": "#3730A3",
   207→  "sidebar": "#151A21",
   208→  "sidebar-foreground": "#E6EAF0",
   209→  "sidebar-primary": "#61AEF8",
   210→  "sidebar-primary-foreground": "#0A0E14",
   211→  "sidebar-accent": "#22D3A6",
   212→  "sidebar-accent-foreground": "#07362B",
   213→  "sidebar-border": "#2A3440",
   214→  "sidebar-ring": "#5AAAF6"
   215→]
   216→}
   217→
   218→// MARK: - Example components
   219→
   220→public struct DSButton: View {
   221→  public enum Intent { case primary, secondary, destructive }
   222→  public enum Size { case s, m, l }
   223→  public var title: String
   224→  public var intent: Intent = .primary
   225→  public var size: Size = .m
   226→  public var action: () -> Void
   227→
   228→  @Environment(\.colorScheme) private var scheme
   229→
   230→  public init(_ title: String, intent: Intent = .primary, size: Size = .m, action: @escaping () -> Void) {
   231→    self.title = title
   232→    self.intent = intent
   233→    self.size = size
   234→    self.action = action
   235→  }
   236→
   237→  private func theme(for scheme: ColorScheme) -> DesignTheme {
   238→    scheme == .dark ? .defaultDark : .defaultLight
   239→  }
   240→
   241→  public var body: some View {
   242→    let theme = theme(for: scheme)
   243→    Button(action: action) {
   244→      Text(title)
   245→        .font(theme.font(.body))
   246→        .foregroundStyle(theme.color(.primaryforeground))
   247→        .padding(.horizontal, padX)
   248→        .padding(.vertical, padY)
   249→        .frame(maxWidth: .infinity)
   250→        .background(background(theme))
   251→        .clipShape(RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: 16, style: .continuous))
   252→        .shadow(color: theme.color(.ring).opacity(0.12), radius: 8, y: 4)
   253→    }
   254→    .accessibilityLabel(Text(title))
   255→  }
   256→
   257→  private var padY: CGFloat { switch size { case .s: 10; case .m: 14; case .l: 18 } }
   258→  private var padX: CGFloat { switch size { case .s: 12; case .m: 16; case .l: 20 } }
   259→
   260→  private func background(_ theme: DesignTheme) -> some View {
   261→    switch intent {
   262→      case .primary:    return theme.color(.primary)
   263→      case .secondary:  return theme.color(.secondary)
   264→      case .destructive:return theme.color(.destructive)
   265→    }
   266→  }
   267→}
   268→
   269→// MARK: - SwiftUI Preview
   270→
   271→#if DEBUG
   272→struct DesignSystem_Previews: PreviewProvider {

   277→        DSButton("Primary"){}

   283→

   286→        DSButton("Primary"){}

   289→      }

1→//
     2→//  GlassCard.swift
     3→//  A glass-morphism card component with blur effect and border
     4→//
     5→//  Usage:
     6→//  GlassCard {
     7→//      Text("Hello")
     8→//  }
     9→//
    10→//  Or as modifier:
    11→//  VStack { Text("Hello") }
    12→//      .glassCard()
    13→//
    14→//  When to use:
    15→//  - Use .glassCard() for cards on solid/gradient backgrounds
    16→//  - Use .photoOverlayCard() for cards over photo/image backgrounds
    17→//    (PhotoOverlayCard uses Material effects for better contrast on any image)
    18→//
    19→
    20→import SwiftUI
    21→
    22→/// A glass-morphism card with blur effect and border
    23→/// Uses DesignTheme colors for consistent styling
    24→struct GlassCard<Content: View>: View {
    25→    let content: Content
    26→    var cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge
    27→    var padding: CGFloat = .spacing4
    28→
    29→    @Environment(\.designTheme) private var theme
    30→    @Environment(\.colorScheme) private var colorScheme
    31→
    32→    init(
    33→        cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge,
    34→        padding: CGFloat = .spacing4,
    35→        @ViewBuilder content: () -> Content
    36→    ) {
    37→        self.cornerRadius = cornerRadius
    38→        self.padding = padding
    39→        self.content = content()
    40→    }
    41→
    42→    var body: some View {
    43→        content
    44→            .padding(padding)
    45→            .background(
    46→                RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
    47→                    .fill(theme.color(.card))
    48→                    .overlay(
    49→                        RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
    50→                            .stroke(theme.color(.border).opacity(0.3), lineWidth: 1)
    51→                    )
    52→            )
    53→    }
    54→}
    55→
    56→// MARK: - ViewModifier Version
    57→
    58→struct GlassCardModifier: ViewModifier {
    59→    var cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge
    60→    var padding: CGFloat = .spacing4
    61→
    62→    @Environment(\.designTheme) private var theme
    63→
    64→    func body(content: Content) -> some View {
    65→        content
    66→            .padding(padding)
    67→            .background(
    68→                RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
    69→                    .fill(theme.color(.card))
    70→                    .overlay(
    71→                        RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
    72→                            .stroke(theme.color(.border).opacity(0.3), lineWidth: 1)
    73→                    )
    74→            )
    75→    }
    76→}
    77→
    78→extension View {
    79→    /// Applies glass card styling to the view
    80→    /// - Parameters:
    81→    ///   - cornerRadius: Corner radius of the card (default: .radiusLarge)
    82→    ///   - padding: Internal padding (default: .spacing4)
    83→    func glassCard(cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge, padding: CGFloat = .spacing4) -> some View {
    84→        modifier(GlassCardModifier(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, padding: padding))
    85→    }
    86→}
    87→
    88→// MARK: - Preview
    89→
    90→#if DEBUG
    91→struct GlassCard_Previews: PreviewProvider {
    92→    static var previews: some View {
    93→        Group {
    94→            // Light mode
    95→            VStack(spacing: .spacing4) {
    96→                // Container version
    97→                GlassCard {
    98→                    VStack(alignment: .leading, spacing: .spacing3) {
    99→                        Text("Container Version")
   100→                            .font(.headline)
   101→                        Text("This is a glass card using the container style.")
   102→                            .font(.subheadline)
   103→                            .foregroundColor(.secondary)
   104→                    }
   105→                }
   106→
   107→                // Modifier version
   108→                VStack(alignment: .leading, spacing: .spacing3) {
   109→                    Text("Modifier Version")
   110→                        .font(.headline)
   111→                    Text("This is a glass card using the modifier style.")
   112→                        .font(.subheadline)
   113→                        .foregroundColor(.secondary)
   114→                }
   115→                .glassCard()
   116→
   117→                // Custom radius
   118→                VStack(alignment: .leading, spacing: .spacing3) {
   119→                    Text("Custom Radius")
   120→                        .font(.headline)
   121→                    Text("This card has a small corner radius.")
   122→                        .font(.subheadline)
   123→                        .foregroundColor(.secondary)
   124→                }
   125→                .glassCard(cornerRadius: .radiusSmall)
   126→            }
   127→            .padding()
   128→            .withDesignTheme()
   129→            .background(DesignTheme.defaultLight.color(.background))
   130→            .previewDisplayName("Light Mode")
   131→
   132→            // Dark mode
   133→            VStack(spacing: .spacing4) {
   134→                GlassCard {
   135→                    VStack(alignment: .leading, spacing: .spacing3) {
   136→                        Text("Glass Card")
   137→                            .font(.headline)
   138→                        Text("Dark mode glass card example.")
   139→                            .font(.subheadline)
   140→                            .foregroundColor(.secondary)
   141→                    }
   142→                }
   143→
   144→                VStack(alignment: .leading, spacing: .spacing3) {
   145→                    Text("Another Card")
   146→                        .font(.headline)
   147→                    Text("With modifier style.")
   148→                        .font(.subheadline)

   150→                }

     3→//  A specialized card component designed for overlaying content on top of photo backgrounds
     4→//
     5→//  Design Principles (Apple HIG):
     6→//  - Uses Material effects for depth and readability on any background
     7→//  - Provides sufficient contrast for WCAG AA accessibility compliance
     8→//  - Adapts to iOS native blur/vibrancy system
     9→//  - Works beautifully regardless of background photo color/brightness
    10→//
    11→//  Usage:
    12→//  VStack {
    13→//      Text("Name")
    14→//      Text("Details")
    15→//  }
    16→//  .photoOverlayCard()
    17→//
    18→//  Or with custom options:
    19→//  .photoOverlayCard(material: .regular, cornerRadius: .radiusLarge, padding: .spacing4)
    20→//
    21→
    22→import SwiftUI
    23→
    24→// MARK: - PhotoOverlayCard ViewModifier
    25→
    26→/// A view modifier that creates a card optimized for display over photo backgrounds
    27→/// Uses iOS Material effects for universal readability and native feel
    28→struct PhotoOverlayCardModifier: ViewModifier {
    29→    var material: Material = .ultraThinMaterial
    30→    var cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge
    31→    var padding: CGFloat = .spacing4
    32→    var showBorder: Bool = true
    33→    var shadowStrength: ShadowStrength = .medium
    34→
    35→    @Environment(\.colorScheme) private var colorScheme
    36→
    37→    func body(content: Content) -> some View {
    38→        content
    39→            .padding(padding)
    40→            .background(
    41→                RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
    42→                    .fill(material)
    43→                    .overlay(
    44→                        // Subtle border for definition
    45→                        RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
    46→                            .strokeBorder(
    47→                                Color.white.opacity(showBorder ? (colorScheme == .dark ? 0.2 : 0.3) : 0),
    48→                                lineWidth: 1
    49→                            )
    50→                    )
    51→                    .shadow(
    52→                        color: Color.black.opacity(shadowStrength.opacity),
    53→                        radius: shadowStrength.radius,
    54→                        x: 0,
    55→                        y: shadowStrength.yOffset
    56→                    )
    57→            )
    58→    }
    59→}
    60→
    61→// MARK: - Shadow Strength Enum
    62→
    63→/// Defines shadow strength for different emphasis levels
    64→enum ShadowStrength {
    65→    case none
    66→    case subtle
    67→    case medium
    68→    case strong
    69→
    70→    var opacity: Double {
    71→        switch self {
    72→        case .none: return 0
    73→        case .subtle: return 0.1
    74→        case .medium: return 0.15
    75→        case .strong: return 0.25
    76→        }
    77→    }
    78→
    79→    var radius: CGFloat {
    80→        switch self {
    81→        case .none: return 0
    82→        case .subtle: return 8
    83→        case .medium: return 12
    84→        case .strong: return 20
    85→        }
    86→    }
    87→
    88→    var yOffset: CGFloat {
    89→        switch self {
    90→        case .none: return 0
    91→        case .subtle: return 2
    92→        case .medium: return 4
    93→        case .strong: return 8
    94→        }
    95→    }
    96→}
    97→
    98→// MARK: - View Extension
    99→
   100→extension View {
   101→    /// Applies photo overlay card styling optimized for display over photo backgrounds
   102→    ///
   103→    /// This modifier uses iOS Material effects to ensure readability on any background image.
   104→    /// The material automatically adapts to light/dark mode and provides proper contrast.
   105→    ///
   106→    /// - Parameters:
   107→    ///   - material: The Material type to use (default: .ultraThinMaterial)
   108→    ///               Options: .ultraThinMaterial, .thinMaterial, .regularMaterial, .thickMaterial, .ultraThickMaterial
   109→    ///   - cornerRadius: Corner radius of the card (default: .radiusLarge)
   110→    ///   - padding: Internal padding (default: .spacing4)
   111→    ///   - showBorder: Whether to show a subtle border (default: true)
   112→    ///   - shadowStrength: Shadow strength for depth (default: .medium)
   113→    /// - Returns: A view with photo overlay card styling applied
   114→    ///
   115→    /// ## Example Usage:
   116→    /// ```swift
   117→    /// // Basic usage (recommended for most cases)
   118→    /// VStack {
   119→    ///     Text("John Doe")
   120→    ///     Text("Basketball • Guard • 2025")
   121→    /// }
   122→    /// .photoOverlayCard()
   123→    ///
   124→    /// // Custom material for stronger blur
   125→    /// VStack {
   126→    ///     Text("Profile Info")
   127→    /// }
   128→    /// .photoOverlayCard(material: .regularMaterial)
   129→    ///
   130→    /// // Subtle card with minimal shadow
   131→    /// VStack {
   132→    ///     Text("Secondary Info")
   133→    /// }
   134→    /// .photoOverlayCard(shadowStrength: .subtle)
   135→    /// ```
   136→    func photoOverlayCard(
   137→        material: Material = .ultraThinMaterial,
   138→        cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge,
   139→        padding: CGFloat = .spacing4,
   140→        showBorder: Bool = true,
   141→        shadowStrength: ShadowStrength = .medium
   142→    ) -> some View {
   143→        modifier(PhotoOverlayCardModifier(
   144→            material: material,
   145→            cornerRadius: cornerRadius,
   146→            padding: padding,
   147→            showBorder: showBorder,
   148→            shadowStrength: shadowStrength
   149→        ))
   150→    }
   151→}
   152→
   153→// MARK: - Container Version (Alternative API)
   154→
   155→/// A container view that wraps content in a photo overlay card
   156→/// This is an alternative to the modifier version, useful when you prefer container syntax
   157→struct PhotoOverlayCard<Content: View>: View {
   158→    let content: Content
   159→    var material: Material = .ultraThinMaterial
   160→    var cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge
   161→    var padding: CGFloat = .spacing4
   162→    var showBorder: Bool = true
   163→    var shadowStrength: ShadowStrength = .medium
   164→
   165→    @Environment(\.colorScheme) private var colorScheme
   166→
   167→    init(
   168→        material: Material = .ultraThinMaterial,
   169→        cornerRadius: CGFloat = .radiusLarge,
   170→        padding: CGFloat = .spacing4,
   171→        showBorder: Bool = true,
   172→        shadowStrength: ShadowStrength = .medium,
   173→        @ViewBuilder content: () -> Content
   174→    ) {
   175→        self.material = material
   176→        self.cornerRadius = cornerRadius
   177→        self.padding = padding
   178→        self.showBorder = showBorder
   179→        self.shadowStrength = shadowStrength
   180→        self.content = content()
   181→    }
   182→
   183→    var body: some View {
   184→        content
   185→            .padding(padding)
   186→            .background(
   187→                RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
   188→                    .fill(material)
   189→                    .overlay(
   190→                        RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: cornerRadius, style: .continuous)
   191→                            .strokeBorder(
   192→                                Color.white.opacity(showBorder ? (colorScheme == .dark ? 0.2 : 0.3) : 0),
   193→                                lineWidth: 1
   194→                            )
   195→                    )
   196→                    .shadow(
   197→                        color: Color.black.opacity(shadowStrength.opacity),
   198→                        radius: shadowStrength.radius,
   199→                        x: 0,
   200→                        y: shadowStrength.yOffset
   201→                    )
   202→            )
   203→    }
   204→}
   205→

I found information about iOS 26's GlassEffectContainer and glassEffectID API. Here's what the search revealed:

## Official Apple Documentation

GlassEffectContainer is "a view that combines multiple Liquid Glass shapes into a single shape that can morph individual shapes into one another."

Apple has official documentation available at:
- **GlassEffectContainer**: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/glasseffectcontainer/
- **Applying Liquid Glass to custom views**: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/Applying-Liquid-Glass-to-custom-views
- **UIGlassEffect** (UIKit): https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiglasseffect

## Key API Components

Based on the search results, the main APIs include:

1. **`.glassEffect()`** - Applies the interactive glass appearance to a view

2. **`GlassEffectContainer`** - Establishes a container that coordinates how glass elements blend and transition

3. **`.glassEffectID("...", in: namespace)`** - Associates related glass elements across states for coherent transitions

## Requirements

The APIs require Xcode 26 or later and iOS 26.0 or later

## Platform Support

For UIKit developers, you can use UIGlassContainerEffect with a UIVisualEffectView by nesting UIVisualEffectViews configured with UIGlassEffect, where the glass container will render all glass elements in one combined view

The official Apple Developer Documentation links above should provide the complete API reference for these new Liquid Glass components.

## Key API Components

Based on the search results, the main APIs include:

1. **`.glassEffect()`** - Applies the interactive glass appearance to a view

2. **`GlassEffectContainer`** - Establishes a container that coordinates how glass elements blend and transition

3. **`.glassEffectID("...", in: namespace)`** - Associates related glass elements across states for coherent transitions

## Requirements

The APIs require Xcode 26 or later and iOS 26.0 or later

## Platform Support

For UIKit developers, you can use UIGlassContainerEffect with a UIVisualEffectView by nesting UIVisualEffectViews configured with UIGlassEffect, where the glass container will render all glass elements in one combined view

The official Apple Developer Documentation links above should provide the complete API reference for these new Liquid Glass components.

I found comprehensive information about Apple's Liquid Glass and the glassEffect modifier in SwiftUI for iOS 26. Here's what I discovered:

## Overview

Liquid Glass is a new translucent material that reflects and refracts its surroundings, while dynamically transforming to help bring greater focus to content. The new design extends across iOS 26, iPadOS 26, macOS Tahoe 26, watchOS 26, and tvOS 26.

## Implementation in SwiftUI

The `glassEffect(_:in:)` modifier applies the Liquid Glass effect to a view. Developers can use it in several ways:

- **Basic usage**: Apply the glassEffect view modifier to buttons or other UI elements
- **With shapes**: The modifier can be applied with custom shapes like rounded rectangles
- **Interactive variants**: Glass effects can be made interactive and tinted with colors

## Key Components

GlassEffectContainer is the foundation for any group of glass components, telling SwiftUI to treat all child elements as part of the same glass effect scene, allowing them to blend and reflect together.

The `.glassEffectID("...", in: namespace)` modifier associates related glass elements across states for coherent transitions.

## Developer Resources

- Apple's official documentation covers how to configure, combine, and morph views using Liquid Glass effects
- For developers using SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit, an updated set of APIs make it easy to adopt the new design using Liquid Glass materials and controls
- Apps do not need to be redesigned; they just need to be rebuilt with Xcode 26 to utilise the new design

I found comprehensive information about `.glass` and `.glassProminent` button styles in iOS 26 SwiftUI. Here's what I discovered:

## Button Styles in iOS 26 with Liquid Glass

### `.glass` Button Style
The `.buttonStyle(.glass)` creates a button with a slight white background that becomes more interactive when pressed. The button appears as glass on top of its background, which can be hard to see on light backgrounds if the button is not that important.

### `.glassProminent` Button Style
The `.buttonStyle(.glassProminent)` gives buttons a background, making them more prominent. The `confirmationAction` placement in toolbars automatically applies the glassProminent button style.

The prominent style gives buttons a background color instead of being fully translucent like with the normal glass effect.

### Known Issues (as of beta)
While you can change the button tint color, this currently only works properly in dark mode - in light mode, colored buttons expand but stay the same color.

### Usage Example
Developers are adopting these styles by checking iOS version availability, as shown in blog posts: applying `.buttonStyle(.glassProminent)` for iOS 26 and `.buttonStyle(.borderedProminent)` for earlier versions to maintain consistency across iOS versions.

These button styles are part of Apple's broader Liquid Glass design language introduced in iOS 26, which emphasizes layered, translucent UI elements that float above content.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Apple's iOS 26 design system updates in 2025:

## Liquid Glass Design Language

iOS 26 introduces a new material called "Liquid Glass," a translucent material that reflects and refracts its surroundings while dynamically transforming to help bring greater focus to content. Apple describes this as the first new major design change since iOS 7, and states that the new "Liquid Glass" look will be the basis of the next decade of iOS design.

## Key Design Updates

**Interface Elements:**
- Liquid Glass reflects and refracts its surroundings while putting more focus on content, and the design extends to controls, navigation, app icons, menus, buttons, and widgets
- When users scroll, tab bars shrink to bring focus to the content while keeping navigation instantly accessible, and fluidly expand when users scroll back up

**System-Wide Implementation:**
- The new design extends across iOS, iPadOS, macOS, watchOS, and tvOS, with updates to system experiences like the Lock Screen, Home Screen, desktop, and Dock
- Liquid Glass brings new customization options to app icons and widgets, including a stunning clear look

**Developer Support:**
- For developers using SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit, an updated set of APIs make it easy to adopt the new design, and by using Liquid Glass materials and the new and updated controls, developers can refresh their apps

## Release Timeline

Apple's iOS 26 software update became available on September 15, 2025, for people who have an iPhone 11, iPhone SE 2, and later.

I found comprehensive information about iOS 26, Liquid Glass, and Apple's WWDC 2025 announcements. Here's what was revealed:

## iOS 26 and Liquid Glass Design

Apple previewed a new software design, crafted with Liquid Glass, that makes apps and system experiences more expressive and delightful.(no content)At WWDC 2025, the company announced a refreshed user interface called Liquid Glass, which features shiny, reflective, and transparent visual interface elements that give the software a more "glassy" look and feel.

### What is Liquid Glass?

It's crafted with a new material called Liquid Glass. This translucent material reflects and refracts its surroundings, while dynamically transforming to help bring greater focus to content, delivering a new level of vitality across controls, navigation, app icons, widgets, and more.(no content)The design refresh is inspired by Apple's VR headset, the Vision Pro.

### Cross-Platform Implementation

For the very first time, the new design extends across platforms — iOS 26, iPadOS 26, macOS Tahoe 26, watchOS 26, and tvOS 26 — to establish even more harmony while maintaining the distinct qualities that make each unique.

### New Naming Scheme

Apple is revamping the names of all of its operating systems. Instead of iOS 19, for example, we'll have iOS 26 coming out this fall.(no content)The versions will be named for the year after major annual OS updates (so iOS 26 for the version that arrives in fall 2025 etc).

### Key Features

In iOS 26, when users scroll, tab bars shrink to bring focus to the content while keeping navigation instantly accessible. The moment users scroll back up, tab bars fluidly expand.(no content)Developers will also be able to build apps using new Liquid Glass materials via SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit, and new APIs.

content.content:
Key Insights from Meet Liquid Glass WWDC Session:

Concept Overview:
- Liquid Glass is a new digital "meta-material" that dynamically bends and shapes light
- Designed to create a unified design language across Apple platforms
- Introduces a flexible, organic interface layer that responds to touch and app dynamics

Core Design Principles:
1. Lensing
- Dynamically warps and bends light to provide visual separation
- Creates lightweight, transparent controls with clear definition
- Allows content to "shine through" while maintaining visual hierarchy

2. Adaptive Behavior
- Automatically adjusts to different contexts and environments
- Shifts tint, shadows, and dynamic range to ensure legibility
- Responds to content underneath and device motion

Variants:
- Regular: Most versatile, adaptive across contexts
- Clear: Permanently transparent, requires dimming layer for legibility

Usage Guidelines:
- Reserve for navigation layer, not content layer
- Avoid "glass on glass" stacking
- Use tinting selectively to emphasize primary actions
- Supports accessibility features like reduced transparency and motion

Technical Highlights:
- Multilayered system with sophisticated light and shadow interactions
- Automatic adaptation to light/dark modes
- Responsive to device motion and user interactions

Key Takeaway: "Liquid Glass delivers a unified design language across all platforms, seamlessly blending hardware and software."

content.content:
Here are the key technical details about Liquid Glass implementation in iOS 26:

Glass Effect Variants:
- `.regular` - Standard glass effect
- `.tint()` - Allows color tinting, e.g. `.glassEffect(.regular.tint(.purple.opacity(0.8)))`
- `.interactive()` - Adds user interaction effects like shimmer and slight growth

Usage Guidelines:
- Best applied to overlay elements like toolbars, tab bars, floating action buttons
- Should sit "on top" of main app content
- Not recommended for primary content areas

Code Example:
```swift
Button {
    // Action
} label: {
    Label("Home", systemImage: "list.bullet")
        .labelStyle(.iconOnly)
        .foregroundColor(.white)
}
.glassEffect(.regular.tint(.purple.opacity(0.8)).interactive())
```

Performance Tips:
- Use `GlassEffectContainer` to group related glass elements
- Helps system render effects efficiently
- Allows glass elements to blend when close together

Key Recommendation: Apply Liquid Glass sparingly as an overlay effect, not as a primary design language for entire interfaces.

- Allows glass elements to blend when close together

Key Recommendation: Apply Liquid Glass sparingly as an overlay effect, not as a primary design language for entire interfaces.

Based on my search results, I found information about iOS 26's Liquid Glass design language, but I should clarify what the search revealed:

## Key Findings:

**Liquid Glass Introduction:**
Liquid Glass is a design language developed by Apple as a unified visual theme for the graphical user interfaces for its suite of operating systems, first announced on June 9, 2025, at the Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC).

**Material System:**
Liquid Glass overhauls existing iOS interface components by introducing a new "material" (which in Apple parlance is a visual effect that provides a sense of depth and hierarchy between elements), which refracts and reflects any element placed behind it, using realistic lighting and shaders to look like a real piece of glass.

**Migration Path:**
These upgraded context menus and tab bars utilize Apple's new Liquid Glass look, replacing the rectangular and often white UI elements found in previous iOS releases.

**Important Update (iOS 26.1):**
One of the most prominent updates in iOS 26.1 is the shift from the "Liquid Glass" design to a frosted glass aesthetic. The Liquid Glass design, known for its dynamic and fluid appearance, has been replaced with a frosted glass effect that emphasizes clarity and subtlety.

However, I did not find specific Apple Developer Documentation detailing "deprecated Material types" or formal migration guides for developers transitioning from older material systems to Liquid Glass. The first search result referenced an Apple Developer Documentation page about "Adopting Liquid Glass," but detailed migration instructions weren't available in the search results.

I found documentation and resources about the `ButtonStyle.glass` and `ButtonStyle.glassProminent` styles in SwiftUI for iOS 26. Here's what I discovered:

## Official Apple Documentation

**GlassButtonStyle**: A button style that applies glass border artwork based on the button's context.(no content)**GlassProminentButtonStyle**: A button style that applies prominent glass border artwork based on the button's context.(no content)The `glassProminent` style applies a prominent Liquid Glass effect based on the button's context.

## Key Differences

The `glassProminent` button style provides a background, unlike the standard glass style.(no content)The prominent style gives buttons a background color instead of being fully translucent like they are with the normal glass effect.

## Usage in iOS 26

The `glassProminent` button style is automatically applied when using certain toolbar placements like `confirmationAction`.

These button styles are part of Apple's new Liquid Glass design language introduced in iOS 26, which creates translucent, glass-like UI elements across the platform.

**Official Documentation Links:**
- GlassButtonStyle: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/glassbuttonstyle
- GlassProminentButtonStyle: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/glassprominentbuttonstyle
- General Liquid Glass guide: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/Applying-Liquid-Glass-to-custom-views

I found information about glassEffect variants on Apple's Developer documentation. Here are the key findings:

There are two variants of Liquid Glass: Regular, which is versatile and adaptive, and Clear, which is permanently transparent and needs a dimming layer for legibility.

**Regular variant:**
Regular is the most versatile variant that provides all the visual and adaptive effects, provides legibility regardless of context, works in any size, over any content, and anything can be placed on top of it.

**Clear variant:**
Clear does not have adaptive behaviors and is permanently more transparent, which allows the richness of underlying content to come through, and needs a dimming layer to provide enough legibility for symbols or labels.

**Interactive modifier:**
On iOS, for custom controls or for containers with interactive elements, add the interactive modifier to the glass effect.(no content)The 'interactive' modifier is available for iOS controls to enable scaling, bouncing, and shimmering upon interaction.

**Tint:**
For especially important views, use a tint modifier, and the tint uses a vibrant color that adapts to the content behind it.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about iOS 26 Liquid Glass performance best practices and rendering optimization:

## Performance Optimization Best Practices

### Rendering Performance

The rendering engine leverages Metal Performance Shaders integrated with Core ML for real-time translucency, achieving 40% less GPU usage for the same visual effects. Performance benchmarks show GPU usage reduced from 100% to 60%, render time improved by 39% (from 16.7ms to 10.2ms), and memory usage decreased by 38%.

### Development Best Practices

**For App Icon Optimization:**
- Simplify designs where possible to minimize lag from real-time rendering demands
- Ensure icons remain visually striking across light, dark, tinted, and clear modes, use multiple layers to create depth, and keep the core symbol distinct

**For React Native Applications:**
- Liquid Glass uses real-time, GPU-accelerated blur effects that are efficient for a few elements, but avoid stacking a large number of translucent views or animating them excessively
- Applications directly benefit from performance optimizations, system updates, and accessibility settings that Apple implements at the hardware and operating system level

### Performance Concerns

While optimized for A17 and M-series chips, older devices like iPhone 13 and below experience stuttering animations, blur lag, and dips in UI responsiveness. Real-time refractive rendering consumes significant GPU power, with users on non-Pro iPhones reporting increased battery drain.

### Mitigation Strategies

Combining Reduce Transparency, Reduce Motion, and Dark Mode delivers the best results for visibility, performance, and battery life. Reducing transparency and motion lessens GPU usage, providing modest but noticeable battery improvements.

content.content:
Here's a summary of the key points about GlassEffectContainer in SwiftUI:

Key Concepts:
- Simply applying `glassEffect` to individual views is insufficient
- `GlassEffectContainer` enables glass elements to interact and reflect light together

Main Features:
1. Improved Rendering
- Enhances performance when multiple glass effects are used
- Allows glass elements to "interact with each other and reflect the light"

2. Morphing Capabilities
- Includes a `spacing` parameter to control when glass shapes morph
- Supports animating morphing behavior

3. Glass Effect Combination
- `glassEffectUnion` modifier allows combining glass effects with the same identifier
- Requires similar effect types, shapes, and identifiers

Code Example:
```swift
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 32) {
    HStack {
        Image(systemName: "pencil")
            .glassEffect(.regular.interactive())
        
        Image(systemName: "eraser")
            .glassEffect(.regular.interactive())
    }
}
```

The approach provides more sophisticated and visually consistent glass-like UI elements in SwiftUI.

```swift
// Basic glass effect application
```

```swift
GlassEffectContainer {
    // Glass elements with shared visual identity
    view.glassEffectID("uniqueID", in: namespace)
}
```

3. Symbol Transition for Stateful Icons
```swift
.contentTransition(.symbolEffect(.replace))
```

- Enables coherent visual styling across glass elements

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about the deprecation of iOS Material properties and their replacement with Liquid Glass:

## Key Information

Apple has introduced a new material called Liquid Glass, which is translucent and reflects and refracts its surroundings while dynamically transforming to help bring greater focus to content. This new design extends across iOS 26, iPadOS 26, macOS Tahoe 26, watchOS 26, and tvOS 26.

## API Changes

For developers using SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit, an updated set of APIs make it easy to adopt the new design by using Liquid Glass materials and new controls.

According to the search results, the old Material API properties like `.ultraThinMaterial` and `.regularMaterial` are being replaced with a new `.glassEffect()` API. Here's an example of the transition:

The old way used `.background(.ultraThinMaterial, in: RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: 16))` while the new way uses `.glassEffect(.regular.interactive())`.

## Technical Details

Liquid Glass is translucent and behaves like glass in the real world, with color informed by surrounding content that intelligently adapts between light and dark environments, using real-time rendering and dynamically reacting to movement with specular highlights.

For more detailed information about implementing Liquid Glass in your apps, Apple has published official documentation at their Developer Portal on "Adopting Liquid Glass."

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about the deprecation of iOS Material properties and their replacement with Liquid Glass:

## Key Information

Apple has introduced a new material called Liquid Glass, which is translucent and reflects and refracts its surroundings while dynamically transforming to help bring greater focus to content. This new design extends across iOS 26, iPadOS 26, macOS Tahoe 26, watchOS 26, and tvOS 26.

## API Changes

For developers using SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit, an updated set of APIs make it easy to adopt the new design by using Liquid Glass materials and new controls.

According to the search results, the old Material API properties like `.ultraThinMaterial` and `.regularMaterial` are being replaced with a new `.glassEffect()` API. Here's an example of the transition:

The old way used `.background(.ultraThinMaterial, in: RoundedRectangle(cornerRadius: 16))` while the new way uses `.glassEffect(.regular.interactive())`.

## Technical Details

Liquid Glass is translucent and behaves like glass in the real world, with color informed by surrounding content that intelligently adapts between light and dark environments, using real-time rendering and dynamically reacting to movement with specular highlights.

For more detailed information about implementing Liquid Glass in your apps, Apple has published official documentation at their Developer Portal on "Adopting Liquid Glass."

I found comprehensive information about SwiftUI Material types versus Liquid Glass differences in iOS 26. Here's what the search revealed:

## Liquid Glass Overview

Liquid Glass is a dynamic material combining the optical properties of glass with a sense of fluidity. It refracts content from below it, reflects light from around it, and has a lensing effect along its edges, giving interfaces a sense of depth and motion.

## Key Differences from Traditional Materials

**Visual Properties:**
- Liquid Glass is a translucent material that reflects and refracts its surroundings, while dynamically transforming to help bring greater focus to content
- The material features a responsive lensing effect along edges, where light bends to create depth and separation between layers
- Unlike static blurs or gradients, Liquid Glass is fully interactive, with elements that stretch, bounce, and morph in response to touch interactions

**Usage Philosophy:**
- Liquid Glass elements should always be designed as sitting "on top" of something. They don't stack, they're not part of your main UI, they're always on their own layer
- Liquid Glass is intended for UI elements that float above content

**Implementation:**
- Apps do not need to be redesigned; they just need to be rebuilt with Xcode 26 to utilise the new design
- To fully embrace Liquid Glass, Apple recommends reviewing how foreground elements contrast with dynamic backgrounds, and optionally using new system materials

The main distinction is that traditional SwiftUI materials are typically static blur effects, while Liquid Glass introduces dynamic, interactive, and physically-inspired properties with reflection, refraction, and fluid animations.

Based on the search results from developer.apple.com, the iOS 26 design system includes several significant updates beyond Liquid Glass:

## Key Design System Updates Beyond Liquid Glass:

### Navigation & Structure
- iOS 26 provides more control over the title and large title areas in the navigation bar, including a new subtitle rendered below the title
- Large titles are now placed at the top of the content scroll view and scroll with the content underneath the bar
- A new UIBackgroundExtensionView allows content to extend behind sidebars for a more immersive feel

### Tab Bars & Search
- iOS now includes a dedicated Search tab at the bottom, making it quicker to access and easier to reach
- Tab bars can support persistent features using accessory views, like media playback controls that stay visible across the app

### Visual Effects
- Scroll edge effects automatically show when pinned controls overlap scroll views, with two styles: soft and hard
- Action Sheets now spring from the specific action they relate to, rather than appearing at the bottom of the screen

### Controls & Interactions
- Sliders now preserve momentum and stretch when moved, and support tick marks with a TrackConfiguration
- Sliders can be configured to use a neutral value to anchor the slider fill at any location along the track
- The 'interactive' modifier is now available for iOS controls to enable scaling, bouncing, and shimmering upon interaction

### Sheets & Presentations
- Partial height sheets are inset by default with a Liquid Glass background, and at smaller heights, the bottom edges pull in, nesting in the curved edges of the display

### iPadOS Enhancements
- Apps now display a menu bar when people swipe down, and the commands API used to construct the menu bar on macOS now creates the same result on iPad

content.content:
Here are the key UI changes in iOS 26 not related to Liquid Glass:

1. Rounded Corners
- More rounded corners on "sheets, list items, buttons, segmented controls"
- Elements are more spacious
- Introduces "concentric shapes" for adaptive corner radius

2. Navigation Bars (Now Called Toolbars)
- Icon-only buttons replacing labeled actions
- Contained icon buttons
- Left-aligned title option
- Subtitle support added

3. Typography Changes
- Left-aligned text in components
- List titles now in sentence case with larger text size

4. Tab Bar Updates
- Floating tab bars
- Separated search functionality
- Global search moved to bottom of screen

5. Floating Action Buttons (FABs)
- Right-aligned FABs in apps like Reminders
- Part of new floating bottom toolbar

6. Other Interface Changes
- New scroll edge effect with gradual blur
- Fullscreen modals now cover screen without black background stack
- Action sheets appear where user interacts

The article recommends developers test their apps with these new native components to ensure compatibility.

content.content:
Here's a concise summary of the SwiftUI changes in iOS 26:

Key Highlights:
- Introduced a native `WebView` for displaying web content with customizable navigation
- Added rich-text editing support in `TextEditor` using `AttributedString`
- Implemented `@Animatable` macro to simplify view animations
- Introduced Liquid Glass design language for more dynamic, depth-aware interfaces
- Enhanced Swift Charts with 3D graphics capabilities

Notable New Features:
1. WebView
- Allows embedding HTML, CSS, and JavaScript content
- Supports custom navigation behaviors
- Can track page loading events via `WebPage` class

2. Rich Text Editing
- Enabled by changing `TextEditor` state to `AttributedString`
- Provides flexible formatting options
- Simple implementation with minimal code

3. Animation
- `@Animatable` macro automatically handles animation of view properties
- Can selectively animate specific struct or class properties

The update aims to provide developers with more powerful, flexible tools for creating interactive and visually engaging iOS applications.
